Description: Two copper alloy utensils in the shape of small, hollow and round "frying-pans" (?) or shallow ladles, stuck one above the other by a heavy corrosion. The upper one, smaller, has a short triangular pointed handle. The lower one had probably the same kind of handle, now broken and missing.
Curator's comments: W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 77 § 76: "two small pans, which from their concavity cannot be mirrors, seem to be most probably frying-pans (xxxix. 6, 7)". See also Boston, MFA, 87.500 deaccessioned, which possibly cortresponds to the “parts of a large bronze pan with a handle” mentioned by Petrie, ibid., p. 79 § 79 (maybe the one published on pl. xxxix, 7), found on the NW Mound with bronze cylindrical vessels (see London, BM, EA 23644 and 1888,0208.146 and Boston, MFA, 87.496a) .
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 77 § 76, pl. xxxix, 6)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.42, p.51-52, p.173, pl.15)
